[[Bob Ainsworth]] | term_start1 = 5 October 2008 | term_end1 = 11 May 2010 | predecessor1 = [[Derek Twigg]] | successor1 = [[Andrew Robathan]] | primeminister1 = [[Gordon Brown]] | office2 = [[Member of Parliament (UK)|Member of Parliament]]
for [[North Durham (UK Parliament constituency)|North Durham]] | parliament2 = | majority2 = 12,939 (29.9%) | predecessor2 = [[Giles Radice, Baron Radice|Giles Radice]] | successor2 = [[Incumbent]] | term_start2 = 7 June 2001 | term_end2 = | birth_date = {{Birth date and age|1964|04|25|df=yes}} | birth_place = [[Worksop]], [[Nottinghamshire]], England | death_date = | death_place = | nationality = [[United Kingdom|British]] | spouse = | party = [[Labour Party (UK)|Labour]] | relations = | children = | residence = [[Sacriston]] | alma_mater = [[University of Southern Maine]], [[Northumbria University|Newcastle Polytechnic]] | occupation = | profession = | religion = | signature = | website = [http://www.kevanjonesmp.org.uk www.kevanjonesmp.org.uk] | footnotes = }} '''Kevan David Jones''' {{Post-nominals|country=GBR|PC|MP}} (born 25 April 1964) is a [[British people|British]] [[Labour Party (UK)|Labour Party]] [[politician]], who has been the [[Member of Parliament]] (MP) for [[North Durham (UK Parliament constituency)|North Durham]] since [[United Kingdom general election, 2001|2001]]. He resigned as a shadow defence minister in January 2016 in protest against a front bench reshuffle by Labour leader [[Jeremy Corbyn]]. ==Early life== Jones was born in [[Nottinghamshire]] and is the son of a coal miner. He attended Portland Comprehensive School in [[Worksop]] and [[Northumbria University|Newcastle Polytechnic]] and the [[University of Southern Maine]], gaining a [[Bachelor of Arts|BA]] (Hons) in Government and Public Policy. Before becoming an MP, he was a [[Newcastle upon Tyne]] councillor from 1990 to 2001 and Chairman of the Development Committee as well as an elected officer of the [[GMB Union]].{{cite web|url=http://parliamentaryyearbook.co.uk/mp-member/jones-kevan.html|title=Parliamentary Yearbook|accessdate=March 29, 2017}} ==Parliamentary career== Jones was first elected as MP for North Durham in 2001 with a majority of 18,681. After becoming member of Parliament, Jones became a member of the influential [[Defence Select Committee]], and also a member of the Labour Party's Parliamentary Committee. His [[Private Member's Bill]], the [[Christmas Day (Trading) Act 2004]],{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/uk_news/england/wear/3746178.stm |title=Christmas store ban set to be law |work=[[BBC News]] | date=15 October 2004|accessdate= 18 November 2015}} successfully passed Parliament, and came into force in December 2004. The Act makes it illegal for large shops to open on Christmas Day. He was re-elected to the North Durham seat in the 2005 general election, with a majority of 16,781. He polled 64.1% of the vote. His campaigning on behalf of people who had coal health compensation payments deducted by unscrupulous claims handlers influenced the [[Compensation Act 2006]]{{cite web|title=Kevan Jones bio|url=http://www.politics.co.uk/reference/kevan-david-jones|website=Politics.co.uk|accessdate=6 January 2016}} ===Ministerial career=== Jones was appointed Parliamentary Under Secretary of State and Minister for Veterans at the [[Ministry of Defence (United Kingdom)|Ministry of Defence]] in October 2008.{{cite web|url=http://www.mod.uk/NR/rdonlyres/77428463-6C55-46F2-AEE4-522FB73D1B98/0/mod_arac0809_vol2.pdf |title=MOD – 2008–2009 annual report and accounts – (Minister for Veterans). Mr Kevan Jones MP. (appointed 5 October 2008) |publisher=[[Ministry of Defence (United Kingdom)|Ministry of Defence]] |accessdate=1 August 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100331231018/http://www.mod.uk/NR/rdonlyres/77428463-6C55-46F2-AEE4-522FB73D1B98/0/mod_arac0809_vol2.pdf |archivedate=31 March 2010 |df= }} In August 2009 he was accused of briefing against the [[Chief of the General Staff (United Kingdom)|Chief of the General Staff]], [[Richard Dannatt|General Sir Richard Dannatt]], who had been an outspoken critic of the government's record on equipping troops.{{cite news| url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/uk/home-news/an-unpleasant-skirmish-at-the-ministry-1776202.html | work=The Independent | location=London | title=An unpleasant skirmish at the ministry | first=Brian | last=Brady | date=23 August 2009 | accessdate=7 May 2010}}{{cite news|title=Minister at centre of alleged smear campaign against General Sir Richard Dannatt|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/politics/6057787/Minister-at-centre-of-alleged-smear-campaign-against-General-Sir-Richard-Dannatt.html|accessdate=7 January 2016|publisher=Daily Telegraph|date=20 Aug 2009}} A series of FOI requests had been made{{cite news| url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/newstopics/politics/defence/6073767/Help-for-Heroes-dragged-into-General-Sir-Richard-Dannatt-smear-campaign.html | work=[[The Daily Telegraph]] | location=London | title=Help for Heroes dragged into General Sir Richard Dannatt 'smear campaign' | first1=Melissa | last1=Kite | first2=Ben | last2=Leach | date=22 August 2009 | accessdate=7 May 2010}} concerning Dannat's expenses, and blogger [[Paul Staines|Guido Fawkes]] 'outed' Jones as the culprit, although he did not provide any evidence that directly connected Jones to the requests. Jones, who had tabled Parliamentary questions on Army officials' spending before becoming a minister, denied the allegations and said he had a good working relationship with Dannatt.{{cite news| url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/uk/8210781.stm | work=[[BBC News]] | title=Minister denies Army chief 'plot' | date=19 August 2009 | accessdate=7 May 2010}} Jones publicly apologised to [[Joanna Lumley]] in March 2010 after he had accused her of "deathly silence" over misleading advice being given to some Gurkhas following Lumley's successful campaign to allow more Gurkhas to settle in the UK.{{cite web|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/asia/nepal/7535165/Defence-minister-apologises-to-Joanna-Lumley-over-Gurkha-row.html|title=Defence minister apologises to Joanna Lumley over Gurkha row|date=29 March 2010|publisher=|via=www.telegraph.co.uk}}{{cite news| url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/newstopics/politics/7407716/Joanna-Lumley-irritates-minister-over-Gurkhas.html | work=[[The Daily Telegraph]] | title=Joanna Lumley 'irritates' minister over Gurkhas | first=James | last=Kirkup | date=9 March 2010 | accessdate=18 November 2015}} ===In opposition=== In May 2010 [[Harriet Harman]] appointed Jones Shadow [[Minister of State for the Armed Forces|Minister for the Armed Forces]], outside [[First Shadow Cabinet of Harriet Harman|the Shadow Cabinet]]. He retained this position under Labour leader [[Ed Miliband]] and in [[Jeremy Corbyn]]'s first appointment of shadow ministers in 2015.{{cite web |url=http://www.kevanjonesmp.org.uk/bio |title=Kevan's Biography |publisher=Kevan Jones |accessdate=8 January 2016}} He became a member of the special Select Committee set up to scrutinise the Bill that became the Armed Forces Act 2011.{{cite web |url=https://publications.parliament.uk/pa/cm201011/cmselect/cmarmed/779/77901.htm|accessdate = 20 September 2013| title=Select Committee on the Armed Forces Bill|publisher = www.parliament.uk}} He was also a member of the [[Public Bill Committee]] for the [[Defence Reform Act 2014]]{{cite web|url=http://services.parliament.uk/bills/2013-14/defencereform/committees/houseofcommonspublicbillcommitteeonthedefencereformbill201314.html|title=House of Commons Public Bill Committee on the Defence Reform Bill 2013–14 |publisher=www.parliament.uk |date= |accessdate=17 September 2013}} In December 2015 Jones made public his strong criticism of the new Labour leader [[Jeremy Corbyn]], in particular after Corbyn opposed military intervention in the [[Syrian Civil War]]. Jones stated "because of [Corbyn's] incompetence, the Tories are getting away with things that are not being properly scrutinised and the people who are suffering are the ones that we represent."{{cite news |url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/uk/politics/jeremy-corbyn-is-incompetent-says-shadow-defence-minister-a6761136.html |title=Jeremy Corbyn is 'incompetent' says shadow Defence Minister |author=Samuel Osborne |newspaper=The Independent |date=4 December 2015 |accessdate=8 January 2016}} Jones supported the [[Saudi Arabian-led intervention in Yemen]].{{cite news |title=The Labour rebels who didn’t back the Yemen vote have blood on their hands |url=https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2016/oct/28/emily-thornberry-labour-mps-blood-hands-yemen-conflict-saudi-arabia |work=The Guardian |date=28 October 2016}} He is Treasurer of the All-Party Parliamentary Group on Industrial Heritage.{{cite web|url=https://www.publications.parliament.uk/pa/cm/cmallparty/170329/industrial-heritage.htm|title=Register Of All-Party Parliamentary Groups [as at 29 March 2017]|accessdate=19 April 2017}} ===Resignation as shadow Defence Minister=== In January 2016, Jones resigned as a Shadow Minister for the Armed Forces, following a reshuffle in which [[Jeremy Corbyn]] had promoted [[Emily Thornberry]], who opposes the [[Successor to the UK Trident system|replacement of the Trident nuclear weapon system]], to [[Shadow Cabinet of Jeremy Corbyn|shadow Defence Secretary]]. In his resignation letter, Jones said he believed that the country had to "maintain a credible nuclear deterrent, while working to advance global nuclear disarmament."{{cite news |url=https://www.theguardian.com/politics/blog/live/2016/jan/06/labour-reshuffle-mcfadden-says-he-was-sacked-for-criticising-apologists-for-terrorism-live |title=Kevan Jones becomes third shadow minister to resign following Corbyn's reshuffle - Politics live |author=Andrew Sparrow |newspaper=The Guardian |date=6 January 2016 |accessdate=8 January 2016}} ==Mental health== In 2012, in a debate in Parliament on mental health issues and their taboo, Jones spoke about his own battles with [[Depression (mood)|depression]], alongside Conservative back-bencher [[Charles Walker (British politician)|Charles Walker]], who spoke about his own 30-year battle with [[obsessive–compulsive disorder]]. Jones stated that he had suffered with depression since 1996. Jones and Walker were both later praised for their speeches by Time to Change, a mental health anti-stigma campaign run by charities [[Mind (charity)|Mind]] and [[Rethink Mental Illness]].{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-politics-18444516|title=MPs reveal mental health issues|date=14 June 2012|publisher=|via=www.bbc.co.uk}} In November 2015, after the appointment of the former [[Mayor of London]] [[Ken Livingstone]] to co-chair the Labour Party's review of whether to replace the [[Trident (missile)|Trident]] [[nuclear missile]] system, Jones, a Shadow Junior Defence Minister, told the PoliticsHome website he was not sure Livingstone knew anything about defence and his appointment would only damage credibility among those who care about defence. In response, Livingstone told the ''[[Daily Mirror]]'' and others that Jones was "obviously depressed and disturbed" and "should see a GP". Jones responded that the remarks "belong in the dark ages" and that mental health should not be used to attack political differences.{{cite web|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/uk/politics/ken-livingstones-comments-about-mental-health-belong-in-the-dark-ages-says-mp-kevan-jones-a6739216.html|title=Ken Livingstone's comments about mental health 'belong in the dark ages' says the MP he attacked|date=18 November 2015|publisher=}} Livingstone eventually apologised, only doing so unreservedly via Twitter after intervention by Labour Leader [[Jeremy Corbyn]].{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-politics-34853430|title=Livingstone makes 'unreserved' apology|date=18 November 2015|publisher=|via=www.bbc.co.uk}} It was later noted in passing that Jones had himself in 2010 ridiculed a political viewpoint by reference to "the nearest lunatic asylum".[http://www.newstatesman.com/politics/uk/2015/11/commons-confidential-away-pret-manger Corbyn's lunch, a Keith "Vazz" hunch and the New Left Book club]. By [[Kevin Maguire (journalist)|Kevin Maguire]], 26 November 2015, the [[New Statesman]] ==Notes== {{reflist|30em}} ==External links== * {{official website|http://www.kevanjonesmp.org.uk}} * {{UK MP links |parliament=mr-kevan-jones/1438 |hansardcurr=1213 |hansard=mr-kevan-jones |publicwhip=Kevan_Jones |theywork=kevan_jones}} * [http://politics.guardian.co.uk/person/0,9290,-7373,00.html Guardian Unlimited Politics – Ask Aristotle: Kevan Jones MP] * [http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/shared/mpdb/html/212.stm BBC Politics page] ===Video clips=== * [http://news.bbc.co.uk/nol/shared/bsp/hi/live_events/forums/html/thewindow_v0t1.stm?04/1080071832 Keeping Christmas Day special] ===News items=== * [http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/uk_news/england/wear/3746178.stm Opposing shops opening on Christmas Day in 2004] {{s-start}} {{s-par|uk}} {{s-bef | before = [[Giles Radice, Baron Radice|Giles Radice]] }} {{s-ttl | title = [[Member of Parliament]] for [[North Durham (UK Parliament constituency)|North Durham]] | years = [[United Kingdom general election, 2001|2001]]–present }} {{s-inc }} {{s-end}} {{Labour Party shadow cabinet election, 2010}} {{North East Labour Party MPs}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Jones, Kevan}} [[Category:1964 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Alumni of Northumbria University]] [[Category:British trade unionists]] [[Category:Labour Party (UK) MPs for English constituencies]] [[Category:Members of the Privy Council of the United Kingdom]] [[Category:People from Worksop]] [[Category:People with mood disorders]] [[Category:UK MPs 2001–05]] [[Category:UK MPs 2005–10]] [[Category:UK MPs 2010–15]] [[Category:UK MPs 2015–17]] [[Category:University of Southern Maine alumni]] [[Category:UK MPs 2017–]]

The Marshal ([[German language|German]]: ''Marschall'') was the highest military rank in the Austrian monarchy.
==Babenberg Marshals== *Otto before 1177 *Albero 1177–1197 *Dietmar 1200–1203 *[[Ulrich of Falkenstein (Austria)|Ulrich of Falkenstein-Neuburg]] 1207–1217 *[[Henry I of Kuenring]] 1217–1233

'''Loyd Auerbach''' is a [[parapsychology|parapsychologist]], [[ghost hunting|ghost hunter]], and [[mentalist]], performing under the name ''Professor Paranormal''.
==Early life== Loyd Auerbach is the son of Barbara Auerbach and Richard "Dick" Auerbach, the latter a long time producer and executive at [[NBC Sports]] and an independent producer of the [[Rose Bowl Game]] and [[Tournament of Roses Parade]].<ref name = "Richard-obit">{{cite web | title=Richard (Dick) Auerbach |url=http://obits.lohud.com/obituaries/lohud/obituary.aspx?n=richard-auerbach-dick&pid=149416690||publisher= The Journal News |date= June 21, 2006|accessdate= June 3, 2018}}</ref> He graduated from [[Northwestern University]] in 1978 with a Bachelor's degree in Cultural Anthropology.<ref name="AtlanticU">{{cite web |title= Loyd Auerbach, M.S. |url= http://www.atlanticuniv.edu/loyd-auerbach.html |website= atlanticuniv.edu |publisher= [[Atlantic University]] |date= |accessdate= }}</ref>
==Career== Auerbach was a columnist for ''[[Fate (magazine)|Fate]]'' magazine from 1991 through 2004.
He was the Public Information and Media Consultant to the [[American Society for Psychical Research]] in 1982-83, on the Core Faculty of the Graduate Parapsychology Program at [[John F. Kennedy University]], and the Advisory Board of the [[Rhine Research Center]]. Auerbach runs his own ghost hunting business called The Office of Paranormal Investigations. He also teaches one online course at Atlantic University.'<ref name="AtlanticU"/>
Auerbach says he gained attention in 1984 due to the popularity of the 1984 film ''[[Ghostbusters]]''.<ref name=AP1>{{cite news|title=Parapsychologist becomes popular because of hit movie|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=266&dat=19840905&id=uwQsAAAAIBAJ&sjid=S20FAAAAIBAJ&pg=2687,352845|accessdate=11 March 2014|newspaper=Associated Press|date=September 5, 1984}}</ref>
He has appeared on paranormal-related programs for the [[Discovery Channel]], the [[Travel Channel]], The [[Learning Channel]], [[A&E Network|A&E]], the [[History (U.S. TV channel)|History Channel]], the [[Sci Fi Channel (United States)|Sci Fi Channel]] and [[TechTV]]. In addition, he has appeared on hundreds of local and national radio programs, and television programs such as ''[[The View (U.S. TV series)|The View]]'', ''[[Larry King Live]]'', ''[[The Oprah Winfrey Show]]'', ''[[Criss Angel: Mindfreak]]'', ''[[Late Night with David Letterman]]'', and ''[[Popular Mechanics for Kids]]''. He's also been featured in the book [[Encyclopedia Horrifica]].<ref name="Platoni2003">{{cite news |last= Platoni |first= Kara |date= 2003-02-05 |title= Talking head for the undead |url= http://www.eastbayexpress.com/oakland/talking-head-for-the-undead/Content?oid=1069265&showFullText=true |newspaper= [[East Bay Express]] |location= Oakland, CA}}</ref>
Auerbach performs a mentalist act as ''Professor Paranormal'', working mainly on the college circuit. He's served on the [[board of directors]] and as President of the Psychic Entertainers Association. He offers guided chocolate tasting presentations and chocolate under his brand ''Haunted By Chocolate''.<ref name="AtlanticU" />
==Publications== *''Psychic Dreaming: A Parapsychologist's Handbook'' (1991, {{ISBN|9780446360562}}) * ''ESP, Hauntings, and Poltergeists : A Parapsychologist's Handbook'' (1986, {{ISBN|9780446349512}}) *''Reincarnation, Channeling and Possession: A Parapsychologist's Handbook'' (1993, {{ISBN|9780446363334}}) *''Mind Over Matter'' (1996, {{ISBN|9781575660479}}) *''Hauntings & Poltergeists: A Ghost Hunter's Guide'' (2004, {{ISBN|9781579510725}}) *''Ghost Hunting: How to Investigate the Paranormal'' (2004, {{ISBN|9781579510671}}) *''A Paranormal Casebook: Ghost Hunting in the New Millennium'' (2005, {{ISBN|9781933177045}}) *''The Ghost Detectives' Guide to Haunted San Francisco'' (2011, {{ISBN|9781610350075}})
==See also== * [[Haunting]]
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== * [http://paranormal.about.com/library/weekly/aa011303a.htm Loyd Auerbach Interview] {{Parapsychology}} {{Authority control}}

{{Infobox person |name = Luis Gutiérrez |image = |caption = Luis Gutiérrez, wine reviewer for [[Wine Advocate|Robert Parker's Wine Advocate]] and erobertparker.com ... | birth_date = {{birth-date and age|April 12, 1965}} | birth_place = [[Ávila, Spain|Ávila]], [[Spain]] | death_date = | death_place = | style = | education = Universidad Politectnica de Madrid |website = www.erobertparker.com }}
'''Luis Gutiérrez''' is a [[wine]] [[critic]] based in [[Madrid]], [[Spain]]. He reviews wines from Spain, as well as [[Chile]] and [[Argentina]] for [[Wine Advocate|Robert Parker's Wine Advocate]] and eRobertParker.com, the bimonthly wine publication and website founded by [[wine critic]], [[Robert M. Parker, Jr.|Robert Parker]].<ref>{{cite web|title=The Wine Advocate & eRobertParker.com Announce Expanded Wine Coverage With More Tasting Notes & In-Depth Reporting|url=https://online.wsj.com/article/PR-CO-20130403-906162.html?mod=crnews|publisher=The Wall Street Journal|accessdate=23 April 2013}}</ref>
== Career ==
Gutiérrez began his career as an [[Information technology|IT]] professional and worked as a business management executive in Madrid for more than two decades for the large multinational company, [[Tetra Pak]], while devoting much of his free time to wine.
He is a founding member of elmundovino.com, a wine website published in Spanish, where he has written since its creation in the year 2000. He has also written for other publications belonging to the [[El Mundo (Spain)|El Mundo]] newspaper in Spain as well as contributing to various wine and [[gastronomy]] publications in Spain, [[Portugal]], [[Puerto Rico]] and the [[UK]]. From May 2011 to early 2013, Gutiérrez was the Spanish specialist correspondent for Jancisrobinson.com.<ref>{{cite web|last=Robinson|first=Jancis|title=Introducing our new Spanish specialist|url=http://www.jancisrobinson.com/articles/a201105241.html|accessdate=9 September 2013}}</ref> He was the main contributor of the Spanish entries for the 2008 book ''1001 Wines You Must Taste Before You Die'' and is the co-author of ''The Finest Wines of [[La Rioja (Spain)|Rioja]] and Northwest Spain'' published in 2011 in the UK and [[US]] and in 2012 in [[Japan]].
== Awards ==
He was awarded the title Cavaleiro da Confraria do [[Vinho do Porto]] in 2004 and received the Spanish National Gastronomy Award for journalism in November 2012 from the Spanish Minister for Tourism.<ref>{{cite web|last=Robinson|first=Jancis|title=Award for our Luis|url=http://www.jancisrobinson.com/articles/a201211221.html|accessdate=9 September 2013}}</ref> ''The Finest Wines of Rioja and Northwest Spain'' won the 2011 André Simon Special Commendation Award in London.<ref>{{cite web|title=Past Winners|url=http://www.andresimon.co.uk/past.html|accessdate=9 September 2013}}</ref>
As a taster, he has won the Spanish blind tasting championship for pairs (with Ignacio Villalgordo) which Vila Viniteca organizes yearly, and he has been a part of the elmundovino.com team which has twice placed second, in 2009 and 2010, in [[La Revue du Vin de France]]'s European blind tasting championship.{{citation needed|date=September 2013}}
== Works ==
*{{cite book|last=Barquin|first=Jesus|title=The Finest Wines of Rioja and Northwest Spain|year=2011|publisher=Aurum Press|isbn=1845136934|author2=Luis Gutierrez |author3=Victor de la Serna }}

{{Infobox artist | honorific_prefix = | name = Mel Cornshucker<!-- include middle initial, if not specified in birth_name --> | honorific_suffix = | image = <!-- just the pagename, without the File:/Image: prefix or [[brackets]] --> | image_size = | alt = | caption = | native_name = | native_name_lang = | birth_name = <!--only use if different from name--> | birth_date = {{birth date and age|1952|10|04}}<!-- {{Birth date and age|YYYY|MM|DD}} for living artists, {{Birth date|YYYY|MM|DD}} for dead --> | birth_place = [[Jay, Oklahoma]], United States | death_date = <!-- {{Death date and age|YYYY|MM|DD|YYYY|MM|DD}} --> | death_place = | resting_place = | resting_place_coordinates = <!-- {{Coord|LAT|LONG|type:landmark|display=inline}} --> | nationality = [[United Keetoowah Band]] | education = [[Bacone College]], [[Southwest Baptist University]] | alma_mater = | known_for = High-fire stoneware | notable_works = | style = | movement = | spouse = | awards = <!-- {{awd|award|year|title|role|name}} (optional) --> | elected = | patrons = | memorials = | website = <!-- {{URL|Example.com}} --> | module = }} '''Mel Cornshucker''' (born October 4, 1952) is a contemporary [[Cherokee]] potter living in [[Tulsa, Oklahoma]], who works in stoneware, porcelain, and [[Raku ware|raku]] clay. Cornshucker is known for his high-fire stoneware, decorated with hand-painted, Native-inspired motifs and designs.<ref name="Indian Arts Board">{{cite web|url=http://www.iacb.doi.gov/museums/archives/splains-archive-2012625.html|title= US Dept. of Interior Indian Arts and Crafts Board}}</ref>
==Early life== Born and raised in [[Jay, Oklahoma]], and a member of the [[United Keetoowah Band of Cherokee Indians]], Cornshucker was inspired by other artists in his family<ref>{{cite news|last1=Jackson|first1=Tesina|url=http://www.cherokeephoenix.org/Article/index/7817|accessdate=April 29, 2015|publisher=Cherokee Phoenix|date=December 9, 2013|title=Cheorkee Potter makes Contemporary Pieces}}</ref> including his grandfather, Lincoln Trotting Wolf's, talent for weaving. His grandfather built his own rug loom on which he made rugs and blankets on the front porch. Cornshucker's cousins were basket weavers and his father was a silversmith, allowing him several creative outlets in his youth. Cornshucker spent many summers with his Cherokee family in [[Jay, Oklahoma|Jay]].<ref name="oral history">{{cite journal|last1=Pearson-Little Thunder|first1=Julie|title=Oral History Interview with Mel Cornshucker|journal=Oklahoma Native Artists|date=March 11, 2011|url=http://dc.library.okstate.edu/cdm/ref/collection/Spot/id/429|accessdate=April 29, 2015}}</ref> He had positive encouragement in public schools when he began making figurines out of wet plaster and metal sculptures.
==Education== After graduating high school in 1970, Cornshucker briefly attended [[Bacone College]] in [[Muskogee, Oklahoma]] before transferring to [[Southwest Baptist University]] in [[Bolivar, Missouri]] working to become a tribal lawyer. It was during this time, Cornshucker took college art class which sparked his interest in pottery. Cornshucker was hired in 1975 to work as an apprentice potter in the Missouri theme park, [[Silver Dollar City]]. This job opportunity allowed him a lot of room to grow because he was perfecting his art every day for three to four hours for tourists. He left Silver Dollar City in 1977 and moved to Colorado where he became a land surveyor. After six months, Cornshucker moved back home to set up his own studio in Kansas City, Missouri.<ref name="oral history" />
==Career== When Cornshucker set up in his own studio, he began to compete in more booth shows as well as galleries. When Cornshucker began to do more Native shows, he experienced an increase in the amount of galleries taking on his work. In the early 1980's, Cornshucker would do approximately 15-16 gallery shows per year.<ref name="oral history" /> Cornshucker also began incorporating his trademark Native motifs on his pottery around this time. The dragonfly was a special symbol for him not only because of its symbolism for many tribal cultures, but also because of its association with his grandfather, Lincoln Trotting Wolf.<ref name="oral history" /> Cornshucker is also part owner of the [http://thebradyartsdistrict.com/?q=business/brady-artists-studio Brady Artists Studio] with Donna Prigmore.
In 2007, Cornshucker was selected to participate in a cultural exchange with African artists, put on by the [[Kellogg Foundation]] in tandem with the [[Institute of American Indian Arts]] of Santa Fe. Cornshucker worked in a [[Zulu people|Zulu]] village and put on a workshop for the Zulu potters. The goal of this program was for the American potters to offer tips and advice on how to better market the Zulu potters' work. Cornshucker helped influence the creation of clay masks and rattles to be sold in the markets.<ref name="oral history" />
==Collections== Cornshucker is considered a modern potter who values the functionality of his pieces while aesthetically including Native American motifs in his signature designs. He strives to create pieces that communicate past and present Native American spirit which reflects his heritage and honors the creativity of man over time. He has shown his work in a variety of nationally significant markets, including the [https://www.eiteljorg.org/explore/festivals-and-events/indian-market-festival Eiteljorg Indian Market and Festival],<ref>{{cite web|title=2012 Indian Market and Festival|url=http://www.eiteljorg.org/docs/festivals-events-docs/2012-imf-artist-list.pdf?sfvrsn=0|accessdate=April 29, 2015}}</ref> the [http://www.swaia.org/ Sante Fe Indian Market], the [http://www.pueblogrande.org/indian-market/ Pueblo Grande Museum Indian Art Show] in [[Phoenix, Arizona|Phoenix]], and the [https://archive.is/20150429182540/http://www.cahokiamounds.org/news-events/blog/2012/06/12/271/ Contemporary Indian Art Show] at [[Cahokia]].<ref>{{cite news|last1=Serra|first1=Janet|title=Famous Native American Potter at the Institute for American Indian Studies|url=http://patch.com/connecticut/woodbury-middlebury/famous-native-american-potter-at-the-institute-for-american-indian-studies|accessdate=April 29, 2015|publisher=Woodbury-Middlebury Patch|date=February 6, 2014}}</ref>
==Awards== 2007 Selected for a cultural artist exchange with South Africa, sponsored by the Kellogg Foundation and Institute of American Indian Art.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=McCormick|first1=Janice|title=Profile of a Successful Potter: Mel Cornshucker|journal=Oklahoma Visual Arts Coalition's Art Focus Oklahoma|date=August 2007|volume=22|issue= 4|page=6|url=http://issuu.com/ovac/docs/artfocus-julaug07|accessdate=April 29, 2015}}</ref>
2014 winner of the modern pottery category for the [https://www.redearth.org/red-earth-festival/ Red Earth Native American Cultural Festival] in Oklahoma.<ref>{{cite journal|title=Recent Developments|journal=First American Art:Art of Indigenous Peoples of America|volume=No. 4|issue=2014|page=2|url=https://www.joomag.com/magazine/first-american-art-magazine-vol-4-fall-2014/0231577001409887002?page=22|accessdate=April 29, 2015}}</ref>
2014 [http://www.tulsaindianartfestival.com/ Greater Tulsa Indian Art Festival]. [http://tulsaindianartfestival.com/art-winners.php Best of Show] 2014 Greater Tulsa Area Indian Affairs Commission. Moscelyne Larkin Cultural Achievement Award.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Staff Report|title=Dream Keepers Awards honor 11|url=http://www.nativetimes.com/index.php/life/people/10777-dream-keepers-awards-honor-11|accessdate=April 29, 2015|publisher=Native American Times|date=November 11, 2014}}</ref>
==References== {{Reflist|30em}}

Miller | birth_date = {{birth year and age|1956}} | birth_place = [[Des Moines, Iowa]], United States | death_date = | death_place = | residence = | nationality = [[United States|American]] | occupation = Film director, producer, writer, | party = [[American Freedom Party]] 2012 [[American Eagle Party]] 2016 | religion = | spouse = }}
'''Merlin L. Miller''' (born 1956) is an American Paleoconservative political activist, independent film director, writer, and producer. His works include the 1998 television film ''[[A Place to Grow]]'', starring [[Gary Morris]], and the 2000 film ''[[Jericho (2000 film)|Jericho]]'', starring [[Mark Valley]]. During the 2000s he founded a [[Tennessee]]-based production company, Americana Pictures. He has also written articles for the ''[[Barnes Review]]'' and the ''[[Occidental Observer]]''.<ref name="barnes">{{cite web|url=http://www.barnesreview.org/html/sept2009lead_125.html|title=Arminius: The Liberator of Europe|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100128054834/http://www.barnesreview.org/html/sept2009lead_125.html|archivedate=January 28, 2010|df=mdy-all}}</ref><ref name="afp">{{cite web|url=http://www.americanfreepress.net/html/patriots_compete_171.html|title=New Film Company says it will compete directly with Hollywood moguls|accessdate=February 9, 2010}}</ref><ref name="occidental">{{cite web|url=http://www.theoccidentalobserver.net/authors/Miller-Americana.html|title=Americana Pictures: Restoring the American Dream|accessdate=February 9, 2010}}</ref>
Miller was the 2012 presidential nominee of the white nationalist [[American Freedom Party]].<ref name=winger>[[Richard Winger|Winger, Richard]] (January 17, 2012) [http://www.ballot-access.org/2012/01/17/american-third-position-nomines-its-first-national-ticket/ "American Third Position Nomines its First National Ticket"], ''[[Ballot Access News]]''. Retrieved January 19, 2012.</ref> Cuban-American professor and political activist [[Virginia Abernethy]] was his running-mate.
==Early years== Miller was born [[Des Moines, Iowa]] in 1956, and raised there as well. He states that he worked as an [[Industrial engineering]] manager for [[Michelin Tire Company]]. Miller says that in his childhood, he admired [[Walt Disney]] and [[Davy Crockett]].<ref name="occidental" />
==Career== In 1989, Miller produced and edited ''Devil Rider'', a [[horror film|horror]] movie starring Tag Groat as the title character.<ref name="imdb">{{cite web|url=https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0588961/|title=Merlin Miller|accessdate=February 9, 2010}}</ref><ref name="imdb2">{{cite web|url=https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0164537/|title=Devil Rider (1989)|accessdate=February 9, 2010}}</ref> In 1991, Miller produced [[David Heavener]]'s crime film ''Prime Target'', starring Heavener as policeman John Bloodstone and [[Isaac Hayes]] as Captain Tompkins.<ref name="imdb3">{{cite web|url=https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0102710/|title=Prime Target (1991)|accessdate=February 9, 2010}}</ref>
In 1992, Miller co-produced the action film ''A Mission to Kill'', starring [[William Smith (actor)|William Smith]] as a mentally unstable Vietnam veteran, Boris Catuli. Tag Groat, who played the title role in ''Devil Rider'', also appeared in this film.<ref name="imdb4">{{cite web|url=https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0368868/|title=A Mission to Kill (1992)|accessdate=February 9, 2010}}</ref>
In 1998, Miller returned to the film business with ''[[A Place to Grow]]'', which he wrote, directed, and produced. The movie starred country singer [[Gary Morris]]; actors [[John Beck (actor)|John Beck]] and [[Wilford Brimley]], as well as [[hobo]] music artist [[Boxcar Willie]], also appeared in it.<ref name="team">{{cite web|url=http://americana-pictures.com/team.php|title=Merlin Miller|accessdate=February 9, 2010|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100312012326/http://americana-pictures.com/team.php|archivedate=March 12, 2010|df=mdy-all}}</ref> ><ref name="imdb5">{{cite web|url=https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0145971/|title=A Place to Grow (1998)|accessdate=February 9, 2010}}</ref>
In 2000, Miller produced and directed a western movie, ''[[Jericho (2001 film)|Jericho]]'', with [[Mark Valley]] as the title character. Retired [[U. S. Marine Corps|Marine Corps]] drill instructor [[R. Lee Ermey]] appeared in the movie, as did [[Buck Taylor]] and country artist [[Lisa Stewart]].<ref name="imdb6">{{cite web|url=https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0285242/|title=Jericho (2000)|accessdate=February 9, 2010}}</ref>
Miller's shift in ideology led him to found Americana Pictures, based in [[Gatlinburg, Tennessee]], Miller's current home. According to its mission statement, the company aims "to develop, produce and market quality motion pictures, which promote fresh talent and the best of traditional European-American ideals."<ref name="mission">{{cite web|url=http://americana-pictures.com/index.php|title=Americana Pictures: "Restoring the Dream"|accessdate=February 9, 2010|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100313003815/http://americana-pictures.com/index.php|archivedate=March 13, 2010|df=mdy-all}}</ref> Americana Pictures' first film was said to be about the [[USS Liberty incident]], which he referred to as a "shocking Israeli attack" on the United States. He said he was planning to produce ''The Liberator'' (which was to be based on the history of [[Arminius]] and the [[Battle of the Teutoburg Forest]]).<ref name="occidental" /><ref name="plans">{{cite web|url=http://americana-pictures.com/plans.php|title=Plans|accessdate=February 9, 2010|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100313012433/http://americana-pictures.com/plans.php|archivedate=March 13, 2010|df=mdy-all}}</ref>
He wrote a favorable review of the [[Martin Campbell]] movie ''[[Edge of Darkness (2010 film)|Edge of Darkness]]''.<ref name="mel">{{cite web|url=http://theoccidentalobserver.net/tooblog/?p=724|title=Edge of Darkness|accessdate=February 9, 2010}}</ref>
==Ideology== During the 2000s, Miller began to take on an increasingly [[paleoconservative]] political stance. He also became harshly critical of [[Hollywood]], claiming that it "surreptitiously seeks to destroy our [[European-American]] heritage and our Christian-based traditional values, and replace them with values that debase these traditional values and elevate [[ethnic minority|minorities]] as paragons of virtue and wisdom....Today's motion pictures, in concert with other forms of mass media entertainment, are the greatest enemies to the well-being of our progeny and the future of our country." Miller has also accused Hollywood of being under "[[Jewish]]-[[Zionist]] control"; he cites [[Kevin B. MacDonald]] as influencing this belief.<ref name="occidental" /> He has criticized celebrities such as [[Quentin Tarantino]] and [[Madonna (entertainer)|Madonna]], saying that they are "dysfunctional" and "come from traditional Christian or European-American backgrounds but are notorious for spurning those values."<ref name="occidental" /> He has cited [[Mel Gibson]] and his self-marketed movie ''[[The Passion of the Christ]]'' as inspirations.<ref name="occidental" />
Miller also spoke at the 2008 national conference of the [[Council of Conservative Citizens]], an organization he is a member of. Miller has stated that while he does not share all the goals of the COfCC members, and rejects "extremist stances", he nonetheless agrees with the group's statement of principles. Miller states that he "doesn't like" [[interracial marriage]]; however, he does not support [[Interracial marriage bans in the southern United States|outlawing interracial marriage]], either. Miller has denied being [[antisemitism|anti-Semitic]], instead claiming that he merely opposes "favoritism" granted to Jews in the film industry. He also opposes [[illegal immigration]] and what he refers to as "wide open borders" in the United States.<ref name="hermann">{{cite web|url=http://www.ngnn.com/65041/content/2009/dec/07/arminius-movie-maker-tied-national-hate-group|title=Arminius movie maker tied to national hate group|accessdate=February 9, 2010|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110714180240/http://www.ngnn.com/65041/content/2009/dec/07/arminius-movie-maker-tied-national-hate-group|archivedate=July 14, 2011|df=mdy-all}}</ref><ref name="tpc">{{cite web|url=http://www.thepoliticalcesspool.org/guestlist.php |title=The Political Cesspool guest list |accessdate=February 9, 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120222232315/http://www.thepoliticalcesspool.org/guestlist.php |archivedate=February 22, 2012 |df= }}</ref>
After his return from Iran in 2012, he wrote on his website that he realized that the people who wanted a war between the US and Iran are "globalists (international bankers and their multinational beneficiaries). They control Israel, the American media and most of our politicians…and by extension our foreign policy."<ref>{{cite web|last=Miller|first=Merlin|title=Donate As The War Drums Beat|url=http://www.theoccidentalobserver.net/2012/09/as-the-war-drums-beat/|publisher=Occidental Observer|accessdate=October 4, 2012}}</ref>
==Political activities== In 2008, Miller contributed $200 to the [[2008 Ron Paul presidential campaign|presidential campaign]] of [[Republican Party (United States)|Republican]] Congressman [[Ron Paul]]. He also served as a delegate for Paul's campaign.<ref name="donation">{{cite web|url=http://www.campaignmoney.com/political/contributions/merlin-miller.asp?cycle=08|title=Merlin Miller Political Campaign Contributions 2008 Election Cycle|accessdate=February 9, 2010}}</ref><ref name="delegate">{{cite web|url=http://www.tennessee.gov/sos/election/2008PPPDelegatesList.pdf|title=Candidates for Delegate|accessdate=February 9, 2010}}</ref>
In January 2012, Miller was nominated by the [[American Freedom Party]] for President of the United States in the [[United States presidential election, 2012|2012 election]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://merlinmiller2012.com/wp-content/uploads/2012-Article-1st-PR-122211-Revised-01-11-2012.pdf|title=American Third Position Party nominates presidential ticket|date=January 12, 2012|work=Merlin Miller 2012|publisher=Merlin Miller|accessdate=January 14, 2012|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121114224414/http://merlinmiller2012.com/wp-content/uploads/2012-Article-1st-PR-122211-Revised-01-11-2012.pdf|archivedate=November 14, 2012|df=mdy-all}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://american3rdposition.com/american-voice/the-sunic-journal-the-american-third-position-party%E2%80%94the-hope-of-our-future/ |title=American Third Position Party Presidential Ticket |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120111195146/http://american3rdposition.com/american-voice/the-sunic-journal-the-american-third-position-party%E2%80%94the-hope-of-our-future/ |archivedate=January 11, 2012 |df= }}</ref> He is the first presidential candidate ever nominated by the party, which was founded in 2010.<ref name=winger/><ref>[http://www.independentpoliticalreport.com/2012/01/american-third-position-party-nominates-presidential-ticket/ "American Third Position Party nominates presidential ticket"], ''Independent Political Report''. January 17, 2012. Retrieved January 19, 2012.</ref> He has gained ballot access in Colorado, New Jersey and Tennessee. During the 2012 election, he received 2,307 votes (~0.0%) in these states.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://uselectionatlas.org/RESULTS/national.php?year=2012&minper=0&f=1&off=0&elect=0|title=2012 USElectionAtlas Results}}</ref>
In September 2012, Miller met with Iranian president [[Mahmoud Ahmedinejad]] for nearly 20 minutes and discussed a number of issues, including what both Miller and Ahmedinejad characterize as the "zionist-controlled media" in the West. Miller publicly defended Ahmedinejad as someone who has been unfairly demonized in western media and who cares about his people. Ahmedinejad gave Miller a collection of poems by [[Omar Khayyam]].<ref name="iran">{{cite web|title=Fringe U.S. Presidential Candidate Scores Meeting With Ahmadinejad|url=https://www.usnews.com/news/blogs/washington-whispers/2012/09/14/fringe-us-presidential-candidate-scores-meeting-with-ahmadinejad}}</ref>

'''Orrin Squire Wood''' (December 14, 1817-June 22, 1909) (normally referred to as '''Orrin S. Wood''') was one of early pioneers of the telegraph industry in the United States and Canada.
The brother-in-law of [[Ezra Cornell]], who assisted [[Samuel Morse]] in the construction of the [[Baltimore-Washington telegraph line]], Wood was recruited in August 1844 to be a telegraph operator on the line, and was Morse's first pupil. He was one of the founders of the Magnetic Telegraph Company with Cornell, Morse, and others, in 1845. He helped set up a telegraph exhibition in lower Manhattan in New York, and built a one-mile line for demonstration at the 1845 New York State Fair in [[Utica, New York]]. He also oversaw the building of the line between [[Albany, New York]] and Utica which opened in early 1846, the beginning of the [[Timeline of North American telegraphy|rapid expansion of the telegraph in North America]]. He then opened the first commercial telegraph office in New York City in the fall of 1846. In 1847, he was recruited to be president of the newly formed [[Montreal Telegraph Company]], which rapidly established lines to Toronto and, Quebec City, and then New York in August 1847.<ref name="wire1">(1 September 1906). [https://books.google.com/books?id=VJ4EAAAAYAAJ&pg=PA409#v=onepage&q&f=false Orrin S. Wood and the Early Telegraph], ''Telegraph Age'', p. 409</ref><ref name="rens">Rens, Jean-Guy. [https://books.google.com/books?id=8kUmt-Q7ySMC&pg=PA11&lpg=PA11#v=onepage&q&f=false Invisible Empire: A History of the Telecommunications Industry in Canada, 1845-1956], p. 11, 23 (2001)</ref> He remained with that company until 1866, and substantially retired following a few years additional work in the Wisconsin area. Duggan House, a mansion in Montreal now owned by [[McGill University]], was built for Wood in 1861.<ref name="dugg1">[https://www.mcgill.ca/fph/duggan-house Duggan House], McGill.ca, Retrieved 20 April 2017</ref>
Wood was born in [[Sherburne, New York]] on December 14, 1817, and died in [[Harriman, New York|Turner, New York]] at age 91 on June 22, 1909.<ref name="whobit">(23 June 1909). [http://chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn83045433/1909-06-23/ed-1/seq-1/ Pioneer Operator Dead], ''Washington Herald''</ref><ref name="sciobit">[https://books.google.com/books?id=aYM3AQAAMAAJ&pg=PA8&lpg=PA8#v=onepage&q&f=false Death of Orrin S. Wood], ''[[Scientific American]]''</ref><ref name="teleobit">(1 July 1909). [https://books.google.com/books?id=MH83AQAAMAAJ&pg=PA496&lpg=PA496#v=onepage&q&f=false Death of Orrin S. Wood], ''Telegraph Age''</ref> Having long outlined Morse, [[Alfred Vail]], and Cornell, he was noted to be the "oldest living telegrapher" in his final years.<ref name="ageoldest">(1 October 1906). [https://books.google.com/books?id=VJ4EAAAAYAAJ&pg=PA477&dq#v=onepage&q&f=false Orrin S. Wood], ''Telegraph Age''</ref>

{{For|the Canadian football player|Pete Bennett (Canadian football)}} {{BLP sources|date=August 2017}} {{Use dmy dates|date=February 2014}} {{Use British English|date=February 2014}} {{Infobox person | name = Pete Bennett | image = | image_size = | caption = [[Nikki Grahame]] and Bennett at the [[Red Bull Air Race World Championship|Red Bull Air Race]], [[Longleat]], [[Wiltshire]], 14 March 2008 | birth_name = Peter Alexander Bennett | birth_date = {{birth date and age|df=yes|1982|3|22}} | birth_place = [[London]], [[United Kingdom]] | death_date = | death_place = | death_cause = | nationality = | residence = [[London]] and [[Brighton]] | net_worth = | occupation = [[Infotainment|Media personality]], singer | years_active = 2006-present | television = [[Big Brother 2006 (UK)|Big Brother 2006]] | spouse = Gemma Costin <small>(2010–present, filed for divorce)</small> | education = | alma mater = }} '''Peter Alexander Bennett'''<ref>''Index of Births, Marriages and Deaths in England and Wales, 1837-1983.''</ref> (born 22 March 1982) is a British [[infotainment|media personality]], who won the seventh series of the [[Channel 4 (UK)|Channel 4]] (now [[Channel 5 (UK)|Channel 5]]) reality television series ''[[Big Brother 2006 (UK)|Big Brother]]'' in 2006.<ref>[http://www.channel4.com/entertainment/tv/microsites/B/bb7/news/newsstory.jsp?id=3012&articleMask=1 Pete Wins Big Brother 2006] ''Channel4 Website'' URL last accessed on 1 October 2006.</ref> He has [[Tourette syndrome]].<ref>Big Brother 7. [http://www.channel4.com/entertainment/tv/microsites/B/bb7/housemates/housemate_news.jsp?id=9 Pete Bennett.] Accessed 21 May 2006. {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20071027175329/http://www.channel4.com/entertainment/tv/microsites/B/bb7/housemates/housemate_news.jsp?id=9 |date=27 October 2007 }}</ref><ref>U.tv. [http://u.tv/newsroom/indepth.asp?id=10534&pt=e Tourette's sufferer Pete 'very brave'] Accessed 22 May 2006.</ref>
==Media career== After unsuccessfully auditioning for the fifth series of ''Big Brother'' in [[Big Brother 2004 (UK)|2004]], Bennett was selected as one of the original 14 housemates for the seventh series in 2006. He was the bookies' favourite throughout the show and eventually won with 61.2% of the final vote.<ref>[http://media.guardian.co.uk/site/story/0,,1853731,00.html "Big Brother - does anyone really still watch it? Yes, one in four of us actually"], ''The Guardian'' website, 19 August 2006. Accessed on 10 September 2014.</ref>
The show was accused by some of exploiting Bennett's Tourette's syndrome. The Tourette Syndrome Association (TSA) initially expressed concern that others with the condition would be mocked, though they later softened their stance, a TSA spokesperson said: "What it has done is put Tourette's on the map". A Channel 4 spokesperson said "Pete's attitude to his condition is a really positive one and that's helped to educate and inspire people [...] "He's a very positive role model and he's been a great housemate."<ref>Allen, Liam. [http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/uk_news/5259916.stm "BB Pete: Exploitation or education?"], ''BBC News'', 18 August 2006.</ref>
Bennett was nominated for a [[National Television Award]] in 2006 for "Most Popular TV Contender"; however, this was awarded to fellow ''Big Brother'' contestant [[Nikki Grahame]].{{Citation needed|date=August 2017}}
Bennett's autobiography, ''Pete: My Story'', was published in hardback in November 2006<ref>"[https://www.amazon.co.uk/dp/0007250339 Pete's BB Book]" ''Amazon.co.uk'' URL last accessed on 16 January 2007.</ref> and reissued in paperback in 2007 as ''My Journey With Tourettes''.
Bennett was lead singer in a band called [[Wobble Jaggle Jiggle|Daddy Fantastic]], but he left the band after agreeing with a record label that he should become a solo artist.<ref>[http://www.sundaymirror.co.uk/news/tm_objectid=17716768&method=full&siteid=62484&headline=pete-to-band--s-d-off--name_page.html "PETE TO BAND: S*D OFF"], ''Sunday Mirror'', Accessed 11 September 2006. {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080317014123/http://www.sundaymirror.co.uk/news/tm_objectid=17716768&method=full&siteid=62484&headline=pete-to-band--s-d-off--name_page.html |date=17 March 2008 }}</ref>{{better source|date=August 2017}} He wrote music with songwriter and record producer [[Guy Chambers]], but failed to gain commercial success with any releases.{{Citation needed|date=August 2017}} Bennett went on to form another band, Pete Bennett And The Love Dogs, which played at [[Glastonbury 2007]] and venues such as [[The O2 (London)#indigO2|IndigO2]] ([[The O2 (London)|The O2]]) London and The Cavern Club in Liverpool.<ref>[http://living.scotsman.com/tv.cfm?id=1666982006 "Bennett makes most of his 15 minutes"] ''The Scotsman'' Accessed on 21 November 2006.</ref>
In 2013, he guest starred on the web series GIFTED in the pilot episode.<ref>{{Cite web|url = https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=kGkPtSdoaHk|title = Gifted Pilot 1x01|date = |accessdate = |website = |publisher = |last = |first = }}</ref>
In 2016 he set up a cleaning business called Celebriclean.<ref>https://www.ok.co.uk/celebrity-news/612231/big-brother-7-winner-pete-working-as-a-cleaner</ref>

| module3 = | module4 = | module5 = | module6 = | signature = | signature_alt = | signature_size = | website = {{URL|zaboji.com}} | footnotes = | box_width = }} '''Peter (Balazs) Záboji''' (25 December 1943 – 3 July 2015<ref>[http://www.digitalhungary.hu/start-up/Elhunyt-Zaboji-Peter-a-startup-vilag-egyik-meghatarozo-szereploje/2073 Elhunyt Záboji Péter, a startup világ egyik meghatározó szereplője] {{hu}}</ref>) was an [[angel investor]] and [[entrepreneur]]. Much of the [[Budapest]]'s success as a [[startup ecosystem|startup hub]] has been credited to Peter B. Záboji and his European Entrepreneurship Foundation (EEF).<ref>{{cite web|title=Five Entrepreneurial Places in Europe Where Hub Things Are Happening|url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/alisoncoleman/2015/06/21/five-entrepreneurial-places-in-europe-where-hub-things-are-happening/|publisher=Forbes|accessdate=22 June 2015}}</ref> He has contributed significantly to the development of start up businesses in Budapest and received the highest civil recognition from the president of Hungary.<ref name=PORT>{{cite web|url=http://www.portfolio.hu/rendezvenyek/eloado/zaboji-b-peter/8584|title= Záboji B. Péter|publisher=Portfolio |accessdate=14 January 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Budapest: a startup city on the rise|url=http://silicongoulash.com/articles/2013/03/31/budapest-startup-city-on-the-rise|publisher=Silicon Goulash|accessdate=15 January 2015}}</ref>
Záboji organized the first European Entrepreneurship Accelerator Program in 2006<ref name=WSJ>{{cite web|url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/SB114954501788471878|title=Learning Entrepreneurship by Imitation|publisher=Wall Street Journal|accessdate=14 January 2014}}</ref> as well as the first [[Seedcamp]] weekend in Hungary in 2012.<ref name=FT/> He was the founder and president of European Entrepreneurship Foundation, which is the oldest business incubator in Eastern Europe.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://techcrunch.com/2012/09/26/everything-you-need-to-know-about-the-startup-ecosystem-in-russia-and-eastern-europe/|title=Everything You Need To Know About The Startup Ecosystem In Russia And Eastern Europe|publisher=Tech Crunch|accessdate=14 January 2015}}</ref>
Záboji has lived and worked in Germany, France, the United States and the United Kingdom, as an executive manager in the telecom industry and a private equity investor. In 2008, he returned to Hungary, after setting up the European Entrepreneurship Foundation. He worked with and supported various entrepreneurship and angel networks throughout Europe. He was a frequent speaker at private equity and entrepreneurship conferences.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.suedkurier.de/region/schwarzwald-baar-heuberg/donaueschingen/Living-Systems-AG-meldet-Insolvenz-an;art372512,402287|title= Living Systems AG meldet Insolvenz an|publisher=Sued Kurier|accessdate=15 January 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://laszlomondja.blog.vg.hu/2011/05/20/dolgozik-e-valaki-az-egymillio-uj-munkahely-megteremtesen/|title= Dolgozik-e valaki az egymillió új munkahely megteremtésén?|publisher=Laszlomondja|accessdate=15 January 2015}}</ref>
==Early life and education == Zaboji and his family left Budapest in 1956, during [[Hungarian Revolution of 1956]]. He attended the European [[Gymnasium (Germany)|Gymnasium]] Burg [[Kastl, Upper Bavaria|Kastl]] in [[Bavaria]].<ref name="Kastl">{{cite web|url=http://www.kastlalumni.eu/burg-kastl/di%C3%A1kn%C3%A9vsor/|title=Kastlba járt diákok teljes névsora 1958-2006 (2011)|publisher=Kastl Almuni|accessdate=14 January 2015}}</ref> After his university studies in [[Leuven]] and [[Munich]], he completed an [[MBA]] at [[INSEAD]]. He also holds a B.A. in Physics and Mathematics and a M.Sc. in Business ([[Master of Business Administration#Germany|Diplom-Kaufmann]]) from [[Ludwig-Maximilian University]] in Munich.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://gentleman.hu/magazin/2014/05/12/zaboji-b-peter |title=Peter B. Zaboji|publisher=GentleMan|accessdate=15 January 2015}}</ref>
== Career == Záboji started his career in IBM Germany with a job that he took in 1970. Later, he joined Siemens, and spent the next eighteen years working with the company in the US as well as Germany. In 1991, he was appointed as the managing director of [[Marconi Communications|GPT Communications]] in the UK. He co-founded Schoeller International in 1993, introducing a new packaging system which later became known as IFCO.<ref name="schoeller">{{cite web|url=http://www.yumpu.com/en/document/fullscreen/4067581/benefits-of-reusable-shipping-containers-p2-infohouse/25|title=Delivering the Goods - Benefits of Reusable Shipping Containers|accessdate=14 January 2015|publisher=Inform}}</ref>
In 1997 Záboji was appointed managing director of o.tel.o, a German telecom start-up. Two years later, he founded the European Telco Exchange AG, which launched in 2000 and went for IPO in 2005. In early 2000 the [[private equity]] firm [[Kohlberg, Kravis, Roberts|Kohlberg, Kravis, and Roberts]] made one of its first buyouts in Europe with Bosch Telekom. Záboji helped prepare the deal and was appointed CEO upon the acquisition. The company was turned around by Záboji, renamed [[Tenovis]] and later sold to [[Avaya]]. In early 2004, Záboji was a lead investor in acquiring European Mobile Telephone Services Germany. The company was renamed Bitronic and is today a consumer service company for computer and communication products<ref name=MM>{{cite web|title=Aufbau abgeschlossen|url= http://www.manager-magazin.de/unternehmen/karriere/a-207396.html|publisher=Manager Magazin|accessdate=15 January 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.podnikajte.sk/financie/c/920/category/investor/article/peter-b-zaboji-su-dva-typy-hlupakov-ti-ktori-rady-davaju-a-ti-ktori-si-rady-beru.xhtml#sthash.sAdgrb8D.dpuf|title= Peter B. Záboji: "Sú dva typy hlupákov! Tí, ktorí rady dávajú, a tí, ktorí si rady berú."|publisher=Pdnikajte |accessdate=15 January 2015}}</ref>
He was a member of the Board of the Budapest Festival Orchestra, chairman of Digital Factory, and a member of advisory Board of many organizations including [[Common Sense Society Budapest]]<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.commonsensebudapest.com/en/about/leadership/advisory-board/|title=Advisory Board|accessdate=17 January 2015|publisher=Common Sense Budapest}}</ref> and White Bull, a forum of European entrepreneurs.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.whitebull.com/profile/peter-zaboji|title=Peter Zaboji|accessdate=17 January 2015}}</ref>
=== Teaching === In 2003, upon resignation from active management he was invited by INSEAD to be one of the first three Entrepreneurs in Residence.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.insead.edu/alumni/newsletter/january2003/entrepreneurshipinresidence.htm|title=Entrepreneurship in Residence|accessdate=15 January 2015|publisher=Insead}}</ref> A few months later he was appointed professor of entrepreneurship. He organized business venture competitions and represented the school as speaker at entrepreneurship and private equity conferences across Europe.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.insead.edu/facultyresearch/areas/entrepreneurship/Newsletter/edition4.htm|title=From Phil's Desk|publisher=Insead|accessdate=17 January 2015}}</ref>
In 2009, Záboji initiated a pilot course on entrepreneurship at the [[St Ignatius College, Budapest|St Ignatius College]] in Budapest. In the fall of that year he launched a program for US alumni at Ybl club. For more than 2 years, Záboji lectured on Entrepreneurship at [[CEU Business School]], Budapest. In 2013, the Startup Accelerator Course Peter had designed originally for INSEAD was launched at [[ESSCA]]. He organized entrepreneurship workshops in [[Bratislava]], [[Cluj]], [[Prague]] and [[Sofia]].<ref name=FT>{{cite web|url=http://www.ft.com/intl/cms/s/0/577ae07c-1c44-11e2-a63b-00144feabdc0.html#axzz3OOlnszaE|title= Entrepreneurship: Dedicated business leaders help new ventures prosper|publisher=Financial Times|accessdate=15 January 2015}}</ref>
=== Business angel === During the [[Dot-com bubble|first dot com revolution]] Záboji was approached by venture capital companies like [[Wellington Partners]] and offered board positions. In 1999, as chairman of ACG, he helped them make their debut at the [[Frankfurt Stock Exchange|Frankfurt’s Neue Markt]]. Since then, Záboji has been active as a business angel and sat on the boards of several new European ventures.
In 2005 he established the European Entrepreneurship Foundation (EEF) and launched the first business accelerator program in 2006 and INSEAD that helped several new ventures in launching. EEF, since 2009, provides several programs and events in the CEE capitals to promote entrepreneurship and build an ecosystem for business creation.<ref>{{cite web|title=Startup Sauna in Budapest – Sep 16th|url=http://startupsauna.com/localevent/startup-sauna-in-budapest-sep-16th/|accessdate=15 January 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.buzznews.ro/115591-clujul-viseaza-sa-devina-un-silicon-valley-in-domeniul-it-ce-trebuie-sa-faca-factorul-politic-in-viziunea-presedintelui-european-entrepreneurship-foundation/ |title=Clujul visează să devină un Silicon Valley în domeniul IT - Ce trebuie să facă factorul politic, în viziunea președintelui European Entrepreneurship Foundation|publisher=Buzz News|accessdate=17 January 2015}}</ref> He also helped build Europreneurs.org, an ecosystem{{Clarify|reason=vague|date=June 2016}} for entrepreneurship and venture capital in Central and Eastern Europe.<ref name=GE>{{cite web|url=http://goaleurope.com/2011/09/08/startup-innovation-hungary-credo-week-day-2-budapest/|title= Credo Week Day 2: The Glorious Budapest|publisher=Goal Europe|accessdate=15 January 2015}}</ref>
In October 2013, Záboji was chosen by the National Innovation Office of Hungary as one of the four technology incubators whose mission will be to accelerate the growth of the local startup ecosystem{{Clarify|reason=vague|date=June 2016}} by receiving a funding from the Hungarian state for 20 grants worth around 5,500,000 EUR in total.<ref>{{cite web|title=The 4 winners of the state granted technology incubator called ‘Gazelle’ announced|url= http://www.eu-startups.com/2013/10/the-4-winners-of-the-state-granted-technology-incubator-called-gazelle-announced/|publisher=EU Start Ups|accessdate=17 January 2015}}</ref>
=== Books === In 2002, he authored the management book, “CHANGE! Shape today your company of tomorrow” (Moderne Industrie, 2002. In the book, he discussed about how he turned Bosch Telekom into Tenovis. Later in 2014, he published, Startup, Felnőtteknek! (Start up for Grown Ups) in Hungarian.
==Personal life== Záboji moved back to Budapest in 2008 and spent the rest of his days in the CEE region with his wife and three children. He was fluent in [[English language|English]], [[German language|German]], [[French language|French]] and [[Hungarian language|Hungarian]].
